@gdtrble in a sense, unless it is also flexible to account for people who need to sleep at different times. But if it comes to the choice to shift that social expectation to create MORE mismatches between inner clock and social clock? Why??

@gdtrble It's hard to be required to be active when your internal clock says you should be chillaxing or sleeping. It's stressful and unhealthy on the body system. It is very practical to have a social standard that's based on the sleep needs of the majority, but it's also very cruel

@gdtrble Most people's internal clock is totally cool with waking up somewhere near the average for dawn most of the year. But a lot of people's is not, and that's not abnormal in the slightest. Our society makes it really hard on them.

@gdtrble and still thrive. The problem is that not everyone has the same "start time" for their internal clock to set their prime activity time to. Some people's internal clock tells them to get up an hour before dawn, and some people's internal clock tells them to get up two hours past.

@gdtrble ...either occur at intervals of time, or are time-limited. Our bodies tell time in a way that is tied to a cycle on which we rise, eat, sleep, etc., and the hours and length of time we are exposed to the sun totally influences that - which is why we can move to another hemisphere

@gdtrble ...change the actual distance traveled. In terms of physics time is more complex and very poorly understood, but is definitely has a powerful relationship with biology. Biology measures time and is limited by time. Everything our bodies do is controlled by cycles, and cycles...

@gdtrble There is a lot of confusion about time being a construct. How we measure time is 100% invented. We have socially agreed on time units that we use to measure the passage of time. In that way, time is like distance; You can measure distance in miles or kilometers, it doesn't...
@gdtrble ...when our bodies are best able to be active, and when our social clock demands  us to be active.

@gdtrble The issue isn't a change in daylight, or sun exposure. The issue is that we have internal circadian clocks, and light exposure can only influence them, not totally change them. Changing the social timekeeper does not change our internal clock, so there's a disconnect between...

... this mouse has been living in her stove through all of it! I don't know if it's vacating when the oven is on or if it has a nice cool spot it retreats to or what, but THAT MOUSE IS STILL IN HER KITCHEN SOMEWHERE. IT LIVES THERE. I am low-key freaked out that this can happen.

...she must not use the stove that much, right? NO. Homegirl cooks like EVERY DAY, and I don't mean light cooking, she is INTO it and it's multiple burners going and the oven all at once, broiling, she makes pizza once a week, that thing gets HOT HOT...

...like tunnels all through the insulation, mouse pee and poop, all of it was a mess and needs to be replaced. She JUST found this out and has been texting me about it. That's where the smell is coming from. So like, you might think she's not much of a cook, right? I mean...

...with it a bit and figured out it was the control board, got it working, put the stove back together. But the smell wasn't gone. So they start taking the stove apart again, and found that the mouse hadn't just made one little nest; it had been FULL-ON LIVING IN HER STOVE...

...a little nest and a collection of kibble. A mouse had apparently gotten in and was stealing kibble from the dog's food in the closet, and hiding it in there. So she cleaned it out and put everything back together, but now her oven wouldn't come on. Her husband tinkered...

This was post-Reagan but before the big push to concentrate wealth upward had really started to crush the middle classes. Working-class people could still attain the American Dream, but that wouldn't last much longer.

I had a matched 401k with stock options. This was just how jobs were in this (at the time economically depressed) area & era. Wages had been stagnant for a decade by then, but since housing inflation hadn't really started to take off it wasn't hitting too hard.

When I got my first job in 1989, minimum wage here was $3.85. My first part-time food service job (and the job after it, and the job after that) had full medical, dental, vision, and mental health coverage with a $5 copay. You could rent a house for $250/month & rice was 35¢/lb.

I will do anything to keep it that way.

This feels MIRACULOUS to me. Miraculous. It's so far from the abandoned trailer with a hole in the floor, eating other people's restaurant leftovers and whatever wildlife I could catch and eat. So far. Shit, this life is a roller-coaster! My kids don't even know.

If anything, I err on the side of Too Much Food. That'll be with me forever bc you don't ever grow out of the effects of food insecurity. But I can't believe I paid for a new furnace, water heater, dryer, and stove OUT OF MY BANK ACCOUNT and still have money for bills/groceries!

...which I was already fortunate to have in the first place. The years since my divorce have not been the easiest. I got reallllly lucky in a lot of ways, and I am grateful for every one of them. I haven't had to go hungry since I was a child, my kids have never gone without food

To be able to take care of my home's major systems and appliances is not something I could have done in past years. The simple relief of not being poor is incredible. Major purchases still stress me out, but it's not like the times I had to pay for housing with a credit card

I'm not rich by any means, but I have to say that I am deeply grateful for financial support from my institution that allows me to do things like replace my furnace and dryer when they break, and buy a used range that fits my kitchen just because I have been wanting one.

I'm not trying to be alarmist. But I do think very much that we need to be a lot more cautious about giving in to the temptation to fully dispense with mitigation measures, because we don't actually know what we're giving into, yet.

The risk of Long Covid after illness with Covid is halved with vaccination, from 30-40% to 15-20%. That is still much too high, and that's only the cases we know about. We don't know, yet, what unknown sequelae may emerge in people who have been ill, after years, even decades.

Sometimes the "mentee" just straight-up gets creeped out and blocked the "mentor" before this happens, but often it's the first moment the "mentee" realizes that the other person is exercising such a weird and inappropriate form of paternalism, wholly unbidden.

This semi-parasocial relationship eventually ends up breaking down when the "mentee" pushes back firmly on how the "mentor" is talking to them, and the "mentor" takes offense because, well, how ungrateful! How rude! How dare their mentee demand to be treated as an equal!

At some point in what the "mentee" perceives as an acquaintanceship, there is always friction when the "mentee" pushes back to defend a normal boundary. Often the "mentor" is apologetic and polite, but their sense of entitlement always breaks through again.

One of the defining characteristics of the self-appointed mentor is that they view it as their natural responsibility to "correct" you if your views do not align with theirs. They may be polite initially, but as their comfort in their imaginary role grows, so does their audacity.

I attract a lot of them. So does every other minoritized academic I have ever known, especially if they are female. Disability adds another layer, and it is usually a very ugly one. Intersectionality is really important here.

Someday I'm going to have to write more about the phenomenon of the self-appointed mentor and how that role exists in society, because it has a very specific place and consistent functions, and all of them are predictable, authoritarian, and predatory.
